comment: Symptoms include small, dark-brown lesions surrounded by yellow halo; water soaking along lesion margins.

disease: wheat basal glume rot bacterial disease
wheat Alternaria leaf blight fungal disease

comment: Symptoms and signs: The pathogen produces lessions on all aboveground parts of plant, but spike infection results in greatest damage. Lessions are round to elliptical with gray centers and reddish brown margins. Severely infected seedlings may die.
Symptoms and signs: brown rust uredinial pustules turn into black telial pustules in late plant growth stages.
Symptoms and signs: yellow to orange rust pustules tending to form stripes in late plant growth stages and turn into black telial pustules.
Symptoms and signs: red uredinial pustules turn into black telial pustules few days after uredinial pustules development.

disease: wheat fusarium head blight fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: one or more spikes or entire heads become bleached, superficial, often pink or organge masses of macrocondinia may be seen on and especially in the base of diseased spikelets. Small dark (blue black) perithesia will often be evident  sometimes after the ntial infection and especially abandant on on infected spikelets, notes, and crowns.

disease: wheat brown root rot fungal disease

comment: Symptoms and signs: The fungus is soilborne. The disease tends to be more prevalent in low, wet areas of fields and in plants grown in acid soil. Under severe conditions, plant stands may be reduced as a result of of pre- or postemergence infection. Infected seedling leaves sometimes have mosaic-like yellowing in late winter or early spring. During jointing and heading, conspicuous, chlorotic, longitudinal stripes appear on leaves. The stripes may initially be diffuse or mottles but eventually become prominently yellow and necrotic on maturing green leaves, usually only one to three stripes and discolored veins are present per leaf.
Dark-colored bunt spores replace kernels.

disease: wheat common root rot fungal disease
wheat cottony snow mold fungal disease
wheat Dilophospora leaf spot fungal disease

comment: Only impacts winter wheat; prolonged period of snow cover required for fungal germination; dark-colored bunt spores replace kernels; bunt spores give fishy odor; tiller number increases; plants become shorter ("dwarfed").
Developing mycellium destroys ovary; hard, dry kernel-like fruiting body develops in floret.

Symptoms and signs:  The fungus infects stem base producing elliptical lessions of "eye" shapes. yellowish brown to tan brown and oriented lengthwise with the stem. A diagnotic weft of gray mycelium sometimes appears in the lumen of the stem beneath a lession.
Following the heading stage, dark-colored sori erupt from leaf tissue.
Kernels are partially hollowed out and filled with dark-colored bunt spores.

disease: wheat Leptosphaeria leaf spot fungal disease

comment: Infected heads develop early than unfected heads; dark-colored spores replace kernels.

disease: wheat Microscopica leaf spot fungal disease

comment: Symptoms and signs: effuse patches (colonies) of cottony mycelium and conidia on the surface of plant, initially white and sporulating and late turning gray brown. As the powdery mildew colonies mature, the fungus produses cleiostothesia as distinct as brown black dots.

disease: wheat Septoria tritici blotch fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: lessions on leaves re broadly elliptical with a tan center and usually have a distinct yellow margin. Pycinia are readily visible as small, black specks in the necrotic ares of the lession.
Symptoms and signs: oval to diamond -shaped lesions with tan necrotic spots, brown centers, and yellow holos.

disease: wheat Stagonospora nodorum blotch fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: dark, elongated lesions on coleoptiles of emerged seedlings. Foliar lessions begin as yellow flecks, becoming brown or grayish brown, elongated, and often lens-shaped, surrounded by diffuse yellow areas. Glume infection by S. nodorum results in purple brown or grayish brown streaks and blotches, starting at the glume tips. often with prominent pycnidia evident.

disease: wheat Stagonospora avenae blotch fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: similar to those caused by S. nodorum, except  not much infection on glumes.

disease: wheat pink snow mold fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: The most important feature is visible pink color of affected plants and the presence of orange sporodochia at snow melt, containing numerous small conidia.

disease: wheat Rhizoctonia root rot fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: Distinct patches of stunted plants are indicative of Rhizoctonia root rot. Occasionally, seedlings are killed outright, resulting in bare patch. Under low magnification, root ends appear reddish brown and taper to a fine point, a diagnostic symptom known as spear tip. Usually only half of a lesion is evident at the end of a root.

disease: wheat Sclerotinia snow mold fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: In the spring, dead leaves and plants are gray and thready. Numerous black, irregularly shaped sclerotia are usually present in and on diseased tissues.

Early stunting and foliar discoloration; limited tillering; bleached or straw-colored plants; limited formation of spikes; bleached spikes with shriveled kernels; dry rot of roots, crown, and basal culm tissue; shiny dark-brown to black surface mat of fungal tissue underneath leaf sheath at plant base; diseased plants easily pulled up from ground.

disease: wheat speckled snow mold fungal disease
comment: Symptoms and signs: Immediately following snow melt, foliage of plants with speckled snow mold is covered with a dense network of light-colored mycelium. Numerous dark-colored sclerotia become visible after foliage is exposed and dries for a few days. Sclerotia may be partially embeded in leaf tissue or scattered on the surface, giving plants a speckled appearance.
Bare patches in field; areas of uneven plant height; stunted plants; reduced root mass with pinched or constricted appearance; fine, sharp-looking, red-brown points on roots
Small dark-brown lesions that elongate into blotches; dead leaves;shrivelled grain with black point; staining of embryo end of seed

disease: wheat barley yellow dwarf viral disease
comment: Symptoms: The quintessential symptoms are yellowing of leaves, especially the flag leaves and the shortening of internodes, resulting in a yellowed, dwarf plant. However, the discoloration can range across greens, yellows, oranges, reds, purples, and browns.

Symptoms:Infection occurs in roots, and symptoms appear on leaves. The natural mode of infection of wheat by SBWMV is transmitted by Polymyxa graminis, a soilborne plasmodiophoraceous organism. Symptoms range from mild green to prominent yellow leaf mosaics

Symptoms:WSMV is transmitted by its mite vector. The margins of fields are often the first and sometimes the only areas affected. Infected plants usually are stunted and have mottled and streaked leaves. Leaf streaks are greenish yellow, parallel, and discontinuous.
